Award.AwardTitle: A Systematic Review of the Literature on How Students Respond to Active Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses one of the primary barriers to undergraduate STEM instructors' widespread use of active learning: fear of negative student reactions. It has been estimated that there are between 400 to 500 published studies providing empirical evidence of student affective reactions to active (evidence-based) learning in physics, engineering, biology, chemistry, computer science, mathematics and geosciences. Many of these studies provide estimates of the impact of faculty shifts to evidence-based instruction. This project will synthesize these affective responses across a variety of educational settings, class sizes, and instructional interventions to increase our understanding of the extent of both student resistance and acceptance. A goal is to present compelling strategies for overcoming student resistance to evidence-based learning.

This project will conduct a systematic literature review that addresses the following research questions:
1) What evidence is used to measure student affective responses to active (evidence-based) learning? What are the relative strengths and weaknesses of each type of evidence?
2) Are there patterns of student affective responses in the published literature? Specifically, is student response influenced significantly by instructor strategies, course content, class size, assessment methods, and the type of evidence-based instruction?
3) Overall, are student reactions to active learning instruction generally positive or negative?

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many previous studies have shown the benefits of active learning, from improved student understanding to increased retention, especially of minority populations in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) courses. However, some instructors are hesitant to adopt active learning in their classrooms due to fear of negative student affective response. Affective responses include enjoyment/dislike, participation/disinterest, feelings of learning, and retention/drop-out. This research project explored how STEM education researchers study students? affective responses to active learning and summarized the findings from these studies to determine if negative student responses to active learning are common.


Although there are many studies that look at student affective response to active learning, most studies focus on objective tests of student learning and only have affective response as a small part of the research. By using a systematic literature review methodology, we synthesized research describing a range of affective student responses to active learning, including both negative and positive responses, to make stronger claims. We included 411 studies that investigated student affective response to active learning in STEM classrooms between 1990-2015.


Of these 411 studies, we found 84% reported a positive or mostly positive response to active learning, only 2% reported negative or mostly negative responses, and the remaining 14% reported neutral or mixed responses. Surprisingly, the type of active learning (e.g., discussions, problem solving, quick questions), course discipline, course level, and class size did not significantly impact whether students had a positive or negative response. These results suggest that negative student responses to active learning are neither inevitable nor common!

 

We proceeded to investigate 57 studies that found negative or neutral responses to understand what these responses looked like. Common reasons for negative responses included confusion about how active learning related to course objectives and grades, concerns about the difficulty of activities, and feeling that there was a lack of guidance on the activities. The most common ways students expressed these negative responses were disinterest and lack of participation.

 

To understand how instructors might mitigate the risk of these negative student responses, we looked at 29 studies that explicitly mentioned instructor strategies. Based on these studies, we expanded our list of instructor strategies, which now includes facilitation, explanation, and planning strategies. Facilitation strategies occur after the in-class activity has started and help guide students throughout the in-class activity, explanation strategies make expectations for the in-class activity clear, and planning strategies involve working outside of the class to improve the in-class active learning experience. These strategies give instructors specific, actionable recommendations when implementing active learning.


The scholarship of teaching and learning is a quickly growing research area, often attracting faculty who have research backgrounds in other disciplines but who do not have formal educational research training. To provide faculty who are starting education research with suggestions and tips, we investigated how authors of the 27 highest-quality papers (9 for each research methodology: quantitative, qualitative, and mixed-methods) built their studies. Our analysis offers literature-driven recommendations for faculty to help them quickly pick up good practices for rigorous research that others in the field are using with respect to eight components of research papers ? research question, literature review, theory, methods, research instruments, presentation of data, description of context, and discussion. For example, we identify example theoretical frameworks and surveys that might be useful to other researchers and we categorize the common elements of context that authors describe.


In sum, we found that student resistance to active learning is rare and can often be avoided by applying research-supported instructor strategies. We expect these results to help remove one more barrier to implementing active learning, which should in turn lead to all the positive benefits of active learning that have been proven by the literature. We are actively facilitating faculty development workshops. The results from this research are being directly shared with faculty through those workshops as well as through research papers in STEM education conferences and journals.
